rows.title: Participants come late to sessions
rows.introduction: Ensure that being on time is included in the ground rules. Before closing the session, revisit the ground rules on punctuality. Explore with the group possible consequences for being on time or coming late, to emphasize why coming on time is important. Ask your group if the day and time of the group session still works best or should change. Use the buddy system: Buddies can remind each other of the session start time or even come together. This way, Coming on time becomes a shared responsibility.

rows.title: How should I deal with a participant who arrives late?
rows.introduction: Response goes here.

rows.title: Participants do not participate actively
rows.introduction: Remind the group of your ground rule that everyone’s opinion is welcome in the group (or use the opportunity to add a ground rule like this around participation). Explore with your group why it is important that everyone contributes. Keep reminding the group that teens’ input and experiences add value to the group. Raise the inactivity issue, and Aask the group what can help everyone to share. For example, split into pairs or smaller groups and share findings with the big group afterwards (this is easier than sharing only own experiences). Also, emphasize the importance of respecting each other’s opinions. Praise makes a difference! Remember to praise every time a participant shares. If specific participants are not actively engaged, ask them questions directly. You can use the “catch the ball and answer” strategy: Throw an imaginary ball at any participant and ask them to respond to the question asked. Low participation may also be caused by participants being tired. Do a quick energiser to bring back energy to the group and get people active again.

rows.title: There is a long silence
rows.introduction: Try to identify why the silence is happening: It might be that the group do not understand the question - Simplify your question or break down your instructions into smaller steps to ensure that the group can follow well. Participants may be tired, especially if the session has been going on for a while. Do a quick energiser to bring back energy to the group and get people active again. If the silence is caused by people being reluctant to share, try out the tips for the challenge ‘Participants do not participate actively’.

rows.title: Particular participants talk too much
rows.introduction: Remind the group of your ground rule that everyone’s opinion is welcome in the group (or use the opportunity to add a ground rule like this around participation). Thank the person who wants to contribute and say: “Let's give others a chance to share as well”. If someone generally gives long responses, you can say: “I always appreciate your contributions. Could you please share a shorter response so I can summarize your point before moving on to the next point?”. Then Paraphrase their point, thank them, and say “Now let’s hear what others think. Bibi, I have not heard from you in a while - what do you think?”. You can limit the length of responses as well by saying: “For this question, everyone can share one idea, so others also get a chance to share.” too much

rows.title: Particular participants volunteer to do activities all the time
rows.introduction: Explain that you would like to give everyone a chance to try out the activities: “Thank you for volunteering. It would be great if others get a chance to try this as well.”, and select another participant.

rows.title: Some participants who wanted to share did not get a chance
rows.introduction: Thank participants, explain your time constraints, and invite others to share in the next activity or session, for example: “Thank you for sharing, I see this discussion is really interesting for you! For the sake of time we have to move on now. You will get another opportunity to share in the next discussion/session”.

rows.title: Parents do not feel comfortable to talk about certain issues in front of their teen
rows.introduction: Explore the benefits of spending one-on-one time together. Emphasize that that is how parents and teens build trust and confidence to talk about more challenging topics and deal with difficult situations together. Help parents think about their own past and about what information they would have loved to discuss with their own parents. Explore the realities and risks that teens need to navigate, and ask what role parents should take: “In our society, do these things happen? How much knowledge do our teens have and what risks do they run? How can we help them?” Explore the consequences of parents and teens not talking about difficult topics: “If parents and teens do not talk about these topics, where will teens get this information?”. Answers may include school, friends, social media. Explore how these sources may give inaccurate or incomplete information and what the consequences are.

rows.title: Participants cannot be reached for follow-up (phone call or home visit)
rows.introduction: Ask the participant’s buddy to update the participant on the session they missed. Find out from the buddy what a good time is to visit or call (or give a ‘missed call’ when the participant is available so you can call them back). Ask the participant to come early to the next session so you can update them on the previous content. Agree with your coordinator how many follow-up phone calls, messages, or visits you should do before the participant is considered a dropout.

rows.title: Activities take more time than anticipated
rows.introduction:
After (small) group discussions, select only a few participants (not all) to share their experiences - until you have gotten the learning points you are looking for. As soon as participants have shared those answers, summarize the key learnings and move to the next question. If participants struggle to get to the required learning points, do the following: 
1. Simplify the question so everyone understands the question (this can include translating)
2. Link the question to participants’ personal experience (e.g. “If this happened to you, how would you/your teen feel?”). Make sure you prepare your session well: Simplify and/or translate words that may be difficult to understand. Know your group: If your group loves to engage in specific discussions, frame the discussion in advance (e.g. “I know this discussion will be so exciting. If you don’t get a chance to share now, there will be more opportunities”). Work together as co-facilitators. Help your co-facilitator to keep track of time - if they go over time, signal to them discreetly that it is time to move to the next activity.

rows.title: Introducing the session takes too much time
rows.introduction: Know the goal of your session: What do you want participants to learn? Read and understand the facilitator notes at the start of the session. Pick out the key points of the session that will help participants master important new skills. Write out a short summary of the key points that you identified. This can be as short as 3 sentences! Add one sentence to link the current session to the previous session (not all previous sessions).

rows.title: Participants question my abilities as a facilitator (saying I am too young, inexperienced, or do not have children)
rows.introduction: You can try to prevent these challenges by putting yourself in the parents’ shoes and speaking of ‘us parents’ from the start of the programme so participants can identify with you. Remember - Yyou can have experience with children without having your own children! Emphasize that participants and facilitators are all equal and have valuable contributions to make (emphasize this from the start during recruitment). Plan and prepare well for your session so you can positively impact your participants through the programme. That will build trust and confidence over time.

rows.title: Participants question my ability as a facilitator. How should I respond?
rows.introduction: Response goes here.
rows.message_1:
Hi!😃Thank you for your message. 
My role in this activity is limited to sharing messages in the group only. I unfortunately do not have the capacity to respond to each individual message.😔
🔑 If you are comfortable posting your questions in the group, please feel free to do so! Other parents may be able to support you with helpful suggestions. 💡

rows.title: Participants suggest a solution that is not helpful
rows.introduction:
If a participant shared confidential information, lead a group discussion on confidentiality:
1. Remind of ground rules, e.g. "remember that we have a ground rule that says 'if someone shares a personal story, we keep it within the group'".
2. Identify the issue and explore emotions: "It has come to my attention that some information was shared, so I would just like to find out from all of you 'how would you feel if you trust someone and they share your private information?' (sad, betrayed etc). Do you think the person whose information was shared, felt those emotions? (they will probably agree)." 
3. Identify possible solutions, e.g. "What do you think is the right thing to do for the person who shared the information?" (apologize).
4. Accept the answer: "Thank you very much. So if you shared information of someone who trusted you, please take the time to apologize to that person."
5. Thank participants for sharing and emphasize also what CAN be shared: "Thank you everyone for your contributions, and just remember, you can share all the skills and songs that we learn, but let’s keep personal information in this safe space".
6. End discussion with an energiser to bring back positive energy to the space, before continuing with your session. If the situation persists, have a separate one-to-one conversation with the participants involved.

rows.title: How should I address parents who suggest inappropriate solutions?
rows.introduction: Response goes here.

rows.title: Participants have a disagreement with each other
rows.introduction:
The key is to make sure to stay neutral and not take sides in the discussion:
1. Remind participants of the ground rules they agreed on (everyone’s opinion and experience is welcome, it is okay for people to have different views, raise your hand before sharing).
2. Then ask the group for other thoughts, to divert from the disagreement between the participants.
3. After the session, have a one-on-one check-in with both participants to check if they feel they were heard or if they still want to explain themselves more. This can prevent participants from dropping out of the programme.

rows.title: Participants share personal information outside of the group
rows.introduction:
If a participant shared confidential information, lead a group discussion on confidentiality:
1. Remind of ground rules (e.g. ‘Remember that we have a ground rule that says ‘if someone shares a personal story, we keep it within the group’?
2. Identify the issue and explore emotions: ‘’It has come to my attention that some information was shared, so I would just like to find out from all of you ‘how would you feel if you trust someone and they share your private information? ’ (sad, betrayed etc.) ‘Do you think the person whose information was shared, felt those emotions?’ (they will probably agree)
3. Identify possible solutions: (e.g. ‘What do you think is the right thing to do for the person who shared the information?’ (apologize):
4. Accept the answer: ‘’Thank you very much. So if you shared information of someone who trusted you, please take the time to apologize to that person.
5. Thank participants for sharing and emphasize also what CAN be shared: ‘Thank you everyone for your contributions, and just remember, you can share all the skills and songs that we learn, but let’s keep personal information in this safe space’’).
6. End discussion with an energiser to bring back positive energy to the space, before continuing with your session. If the situation persists, have a separate one-on-one conversation with the participants involved.

rows.title: Participants only share positive emotions during check-in
rows.introduction: During the first group sessions, you are still building a relationship and trust in the group, so people may not share how they really feel (especially if people are not used to sharing their emotions). If you see by session 3 that people only share positive emotions. In the next session I model how negative emotions can be shared by sharing your own challenging emotion. Remember to remind participants that all emotions are normal and welcome in the space. When practicing using the I feel statement, participants may learn to share challenging emotions.

rows.title: A participant is disclosing abuse, neglect or exploitation. What do I do?
rows.introduction:
**During disclosure:**
💚 Provide a safe environment in which the participant can share their story.
👂 Listen carefully to the participant and take notes: what/when/where/who.
❗ Determine if the participant is in immediate danger and what help is available.
💙 Make sure that the participant feels that you believe him/her.
🌷 Let them know they have done the right thing by sharing their story with you.
✨ Be supportive and free of judgement in your responses – avoid blaming at all times!
➡️ Let the participant know that you will share what he/she told you with your supervisor to find a way to support and protect him/her.
📝 Explain what you are going to do next.
 ✅ Notify @global.supervisor_name at @global.supervisor_contact.

rows.title: A parent reports having a violent spouse.
rows.introduction:
1. Go back to the Safeguarding Information on the @global.app_name and following guidelines for handling disclosures of abuse, neglect, and violence from participants.
2. Notify @global.supervisor_name at @global.supervisor_contact.

rows.title: What can I do **after** a participant discloses abuse, neglect or exploitation?
rows.introduction:
**After disclosure:**
❌ Avoid engaging with alleged abuser – that may make things worse and make next steps difficult. It could also jeopardise future legal proceedings.
🌷 You are not alone. Get help from your supervisor to agree on next steps.

rows.title: How can I report abuse?
rows.introduction:
✅ Follow your organisation’s protocol.
📝 If your organisation needs assistance in developing or improving their policies and procedures, please reference the following resources:

**Malaysian resources**
1️⃣ Ministry of Women, Family and Community Development: https://www.kpwkm.gov.my/kpwkm/index.php?r=portal/about&id=b0J5ZFBERFhsalo2U05TWk1nSzVDQT09 
2️⃣ Women’s Aid Organisation: https://wao.org.my/
3️⃣ Protect and Save the Children: https://www.psthechildren.org.my/resources.html 

**International resources**
1️⃣ World Health Organization Guidelines Responding to Children and Adolescents who have Been Sexually Abused:https://www.who.int/reproductivehealth/publications/violence/clinical-response-csa/en/ 
2️⃣ Keeping Children Safe: https://www.keepingchildrensafe.global/ 
3️⃣ Caring for Child Survivors of Sexual Abuse:http://www.unicef.org/protection/files/IRC_CCSGuide_FullGuide_lowres.pdf 
4️⃣ Strengthening Linkages between Clinical and Social Services for Children and Adolescents who have Experienced Sexual Violence: A Companion Guide:https://aidsfree.usaid.gov/resources/strengthening-linkages-between-clinical-and-social-services-children-and-adolescents-who 
5️⃣ Together for Girls: Every Hour Matters: https://www.togetherforgirls.org/announcing-new-resource-every-hour-matters-youth-engagement-toolkits/

rows.title: If a participant wants to know how to report abuse, neglect or violence, what contact information should I give them?
rows.introduction:
You can share the following information with the participant:
Ministry of Women, Family and Community Development’s Talian Kasih 24-Hour Hotline for abuse, neglect, and violence: 15999 or SMS/WhatsApp +6019-261-5999

rows.title: If a participant wants to know free and confidential services to discuss their crisis, what hotlines can I share with them?
rows.introduction:
You can share any of the following contact numbers with the participant:
1️⃣ Abuse, neglect, violence, poverty, and juvenile delinquency:Talian Kasih by Ministry Women, Family and Community Developmenthttps://www.kpwkm.gov.my/kpwkm/index.php?r=portal/full&id=NGtVYXZIMjRqM3diWmV2K005Mm9Hdz09 15999 (Call)+6019-261-5999 (SMS or WhatsApp)
2️⃣ Abuse of women and children: 
Women’s Aid Organisation (WAO) 
https://wao.org.my/+603-7956-3488 (Call)+6018-988-8058 (SMS or WhatsApp TINA)
3️⃣ Emotional distress and suicidal thoughts:Befrienders Kuala Lumpur
https://www.befrienders.org.my/ +603-7627-2929 (Call)sam@befrienders.org.my (Email)
4️⃣ Cybersecurity incident  
Cyber999 by CyberSecurity Malaysia, Ministry of Communications and Multimedia (or K-KOMM)https://www.mycert.org.my/portal/online-form?id=7a911418-9e84-4e48-84d3-aa8a4fe55f16

rows.title: I forgot to do an activity or a building block. What should I do?
rows.introduction: If your chat goes silent after the prompt, consider sharing these ideas or suggestions:
rows.message_1:
One-on-One Time with children is helpful because: 
💙 It improves the relationship between parents/caregivers and children.
🌷 Children feel that they are valuable and loved.
⚽ It shows children that what they are doing is important.
⭐ It builds self-esteem of children and makes them feel important.
👂 It increases trust and improves communication between parents/caregivers and children.
🚲 It helps children develop and explore the world.
🎨 It gives parents/caregivers a chance to learn about children's interests and abilities.

rows.title: A parent cannot complete one-on-one time with their child daily.
rows.introduction:
That's okay! Parenting can be challenging and many obstacles can get in the way. Remember, your job isn't to solve their problems, but enable a conversation between parents to support one another. 🔄
You can share the following message if other parents don't offer support:
rows.message_1:
It can be hard to find time, especially when you have work, chores, and other responsibilities to do. 😔 You could try the following suggestions to spend one-on-one time with your child:
🌱 Find a chore to do together!
🎨 Try doing something that is fun for both of you.
📱 Ask your child to show something on the gadget if they are always looking at their gadgets.
🌷 You can ask another adult to help if all your children want one-on-one time.
💛 You can also tell each child when you are spending one-on-one time and with who. 
🔄 You can change the order the next time you want to spend one-on-one time!
⏰ It helps to be clear about how much time you have and warn your child when time is coming to an end.

rows.title: Talking about emotions can be new to many parents.
rows.introduction: It is completely normal for parents to have difficulty talking about their emotions and expressing their feelings. You can share the following message to encourage parents who having trouble talking about their emotions and feelings:
rows.message_1:
I understand that showing emotions with your spouse or children can be hard. 😔 Many of us were told not to cry or show our feelings to others, especially to our children. 💛 

🔑This group is a safe space for you to practise! If you are comfortable, you can try to recognise your own emotions and communicate about them in this group. 😃 
💡 Talking about feelings is not just for negative emotions. 😒😔😣 
✅ You may realise that you feel different emotions, and some of them could be positive. When you try to name the feelings you have, you may realise that you also feel a lot of happiness, calmness, and gratitude about some things. ⭐💚
✨ When I try to recognise my emotions, I realise I am nervous and excited about being responsible for your learning. But at the same time, I am very happy that you have a safe space to share and support each other. 🌷

rows.title: A parent may be confused about how to navigate emotions with different genders.
rows.introduction: While girls and women are typically seen as more emotional compared to boys and men, that is not true because emotions are the same for humans. You can share the following message to assure parents that emotions are the same for both genders:
rows.message_1:
💡 Boys and men have the same feelings as girls and women.
😣 Many people are taught not to cry when they are sad. This might be especially true for boys and men.
⭐ Boys and men can show emotions without feeling less manly. When boys and men share their emotions, it does not reduce their sense of masculinity. 
🔑 In fact, sharing emotions is a sign of courage and strength.

rows.title: A parent may not know how to accept negative emotions from their children.
rows.introduction: This is especially hard when children are told to be polite to their elders all the time. You can share the following message with parents to tell them that they are doing a good job and that negative emotions are not necessarily a bad thing:
rows.message_1:
🌷 You may feel upset 😔 when your child shows negative emotions, but I am sure you are doing everything you can to be an amazing parent! ⭐
💡 It’s alright, take a deep breathe. Negative 😣 emotions are just as normal as positive 😃 emotions. 
✨ As a caregiver, you can help your children to be aware of their emotions by helping them to name their emotions. 📝
🔑 When parents and children are aware of what exactly they are feeling and why they are feeling that way, everyone can learn to manage their emotions in a healthy manner. 💙

rows.title: A parent is advising other parents in the group to send their children to tuition classes
rows.introduction: It’s good that parents are motivated for help their children learn, but at a young age it’s important to keep learning fun, so you can share this message:
rows.message_1:
It’s great that you’re motivated to help your child learn and be successful in school, but it’s also important that your child enjoys learning, especially while they are little! 😃
If learning is too serious and pressured, your child won’t enjoy it, and might be discouraged from learning ❌The best way to prepare your child for success in school is to introduce them to reading and maths in a fun way. ✅
Children will enjoy reading books with you, will learn new words, and can start learning letters and how to read. 📖 Counting games, and sorting and ordering objects will help them learn early maths skills too! 🔟

rows.title: A parent says that they don’t have children’s books in their home
rows.introduction: Not all families have access to children’s books. You can share this message about accessing e-books, and using other materials that parents will probably have access to:
rows.message_1:
😃 It’s okay if you don’t have children’s books in your home! You can still help your child learn to read by using anything with pictures or words on it! 🍞⭐🚗 Magazines and newspapers are great! You can point at the pictures and describe them, and show children the letters on the page. You can help children learn letters by pointing at them on labels, signs, and anywhere else you see them! 👀
💡If you want, you can download some children’s ebooks using this link, and you can read them with your child on any electronic device in the same way as you would with a book!

rows.title: A parent is concerned that they don’t have anything useful to teach their children, or that they don’t know how
rows.introduction: Parents might think that they have to teach their child complicated things, but actually they can keep things very simple. Share this message to reassure them:
rows.message_1:
🌷 It’s great that you care about your child learning in the best way possible. But it’s important to remember to keep things simple. 
💚The important thing is to talk to your child and to play with them. ✨ Describing things, asking questions, and exploring what your child says will help your child learn language skills, which are one of the most important things for learning in school. 🎓
Playing with children should be light and fun, and can be something as simple as counting ingredients in cooking, the number of socks when sorting clean clothes, or grouping things by colour, shape or size. 🔵 🔴 🔶 🔷

rows.title: A parents says they have difficulty finding time to help their child to learn
rows.introduction: Parents are often very busy, especially if they work. Share this message with them to give them advice on how to help their child learn when they don’t have much time:
rows.message_1:
It can be difficult to find time to help your child learn, but there are two important things to remember:
1️⃣ Your child can learn a lot just by joining in activities you do in your normal routine. Going shopping for food, sorting clothes, and cooking are great opportunities to talk to your child and for them to learn. 🍅 Describe what you are doing and ask questions. If you can, play counting games, and point out numbers, shapes and letters that you see. For example, square signs and round signs, and numbers and letters on labels. 🔷 🔵
2️⃣ You can help your child learn by spending just a short amount of time specifically on a learning activity. For example, can you find 5 minutes in the evening to look at pictures together or read a children’s book? 📖

rows.title: A parent asks for the recommended daily intake of food categories.
rows.introduction: It’s great that parents want to learn about the type and quantity of food that their children should consume. If no one else responds, you can share the following message:
rows.message_1:
🍞 It's great to hear that you are interested to learn about the recommended daily intake for your children! ☀️ Every day, make sure each child has:
🍚 2-3 servings of carbohydrates. 1 serving could be: 2 spoons of rice, 2 slices of bread, 1 sweet potato, 1 cup of noodles with soup, or 6 cream crackers.
🍅 3-4 servings of fruits and vegetables. 1 serving could be: 4 tablespoons of cooked leafy vegetables, ½ cup of other vegetables, 1 medium-sized fruit, 8 grapes, or 4 prunes.
💚 1-2 servings of dairy products and protein. 1 serving could be: 1 kembong fish, 1 slice of tenggiri fish, 1 chicken thigh, ⅔ cup of anchovies, 2 eggs, 1 cup of lentils, 2 pieces of tempeh/tofu, 1 glass of milk, 1 cup of yoghurt, or 1 slice of cheese.
🚩 Just a little bit of oil, fat, processed sugar, and salt.

rows.title: A parent wants to know more about healthy food habits to practise at home so their children learn the same habits.
rows.introduction: Adults in the house can set a good example for their children on healthy eating habits. You can share the following message to give parents ideas on how to cultivate good habits at home:
rows.message_1:
⭐ Making healthy food choices as a family is a good way to teach your children to do the same! 
👀 Your children will observe and learn from the eating habits of people around them. 
✅ Healthy food habits include eating more vegetables and fruits. 
❌ Unhealthy food choices include oil, fat, salt, and processed sugar. 
❗On the whole, your family should consume more fresh food items 🌱 instead of highly processed items 🎂 or fast food. 
⏰ Have consistent eating times so that your children don’t overeat or develop stomach issues from snacking all the time. 
🔶 Remember to enjoy a variety of food in moderation!

rows.title: A parent is personally messaging me or calling me with lots of questions on their parenting habits or child’s misbehaviours.
rows.introduction:
1. Notify @global.supervisor_name at @global.supervisor_contact.
2. Send the parent this message personally:
rows.message_1:
Hi!😃Thank you for your message. 
My role in this activity is limited to sharing messages in the group only. I unfortunately do not have the capacity to respond to each individual message.😔
🔑 If you are comfortable posting your questions in the group, please feel free to do so! Other parents may be able to support you with helpful suggestions. 💡

rows.title: A parent/spouse may have difficulty asking for help in sharing household or childcare responsibilities.
rows.introduction: It is completely normal for parents to have difficulty asking for help. You can share the following message to encourage parents with some tips on sharing parenting responsibilities:
rows.message_1:
It is okay to struggle asking for help from your spouse. Here are some tips that you might find helpful for sharing responsibilities: 
🌱Make sure your partner is calm and in a good mood.
🔑Explain in a calm voice why you would like to share some responsibilities (or more support)
💛Use “I” statements and share how you feel
👂Allow your spouse to express how s/he feels
🍚Allow your spouse to choose what responsibilities s/he could take on
🌙Make a Specific, Positive, and Realistic plan. For example, “I will help out with bedtime routines on every other day”
⭐Thank your spouse for the conversation
🏆Praise your spouse whenever s/he helps out with responsibilities!
